body:
@sunny1401 thanks for filing! Note that you can specify the default artifact URI to use for experiments created under an MLflow server via the `--default-artifact-root` argument to `mlflow server`, e.g. by running your server via a command like `mlflow server --default-artifact-root s3://your-s3-bucket`. Given that the default artifact URI can be specified in this manner, would you be able to clarify why your workflow involves passing an artifact URI explicitly to `create_experiment`? It seems you could avoid the need for this by setting the default artifact URI when you run the server.

Thanks again!

Hi - Thanks for replying. Yes, I can do that. But in case you are working on multiple projects - each having its own artifact location - as different s3 buckets and different locations on s3 - this approach would not work. In my case, I  have an s3 bucket where data should generally go once the code is finalized. This is set in os.environ['MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_URI']. Our tracking URI is rds database

However, simultaneously we have experiments running - for these - if the user passes in the artifact_location - that is where the experiment will be created.  In case the user passes in the artifact_location for their experiment - artifacts will be stored there. These can be set to os.environ['MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_URI']

For simultaneous access/availability - we don't start the server before logging. 

Let me know if there is a better way to it - currently, we applying a patch to create_experiments setting the default value of artifact_path = os.environ['MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_URI']

Hello @smurching - by simultaneous access I meant - while running multiple experiments on Jupyter notebooks, where locations can be different. Yeah - projects which are completely different can be in separate s3 buckets - but individuals working on the same project can have multiple folders in the same bucket - simply to allow clarity of organization and independence and privacy amongst things. Having a patch also allows the user to not have to worry too much about the boilerplate functions. Thank you for replying.
I was able to complete my requirement by building a wrapper around the function.

I am trying to set where the model artifact should be written to so that the MLFlow server can find them but it seems that `MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_URI` does not do anything. 

Is there a way so that not each Data scientist have to write the same `artifact_location` over and over ? 

It seems that this issue talk about the issue but I dont see a resolution.

> @sunny1401 thanks for filing! Note that you can specify the default artifact URI to use for experiments created under an MLflow server via the `--default-artifact-root` argument to `mlflow server`, e.g. by running your server via a command like `mlflow server --default-artifact-root s3://your-s3-bucket`. Given that the default artifact URI can be specified in this manner, would you be able to clarify why your workflow involves passing an artifact URI explicitly to `create_experiment`? It seems you could avoid the need for this by setting the default artifact URI when you run the server.
> 
> Thanks again!

It seems that does not work if the path is a local path. I am building a POC with `docker-compose` and both the client and server will write to their path in their own container but it is the same local folder on the host machine. 
Just so i dont have to set up S3 connection and permission etc... for a POC.

I could be wrong but I think if you have a custom location you need to add MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_URI as a environment variable in bash profile. So in my case every person logging has this location set in their bash profile- and mlflow reads it from there.. also if your location is different from the set location at MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_ URI then u can pass artifact location while creating experiment. But for this your should have the server running.

So I have the server running on container1 , and the client with jupyter on container2 . Both are sharing a volume when i start the docker images.

The metrics are being submitted correctly, I see them in the UI of MLFlow. 

But the `mlflow.sklearn.log_model` write to `./tmp/mlflow` .

On container2 `MLFLOW_ARTIFACT_URI` is set to the local folder attached to the same volume on the host.
But it doesn't seem to read it at all :/
This is a screenshot of the terminal from within Jupyter on container2
But when I call `mlflow.sklearn.log_model` it goes to the wrong place:
Did you try logging files using log_artifact and check if other artifacts are getting logged correctly.?

I am using the examples from the mlflow repo. 
What should I change ?
this is what is inside the output folders

What I meant was like probably confirming if the artifact location is being read by both containers- so I would try running the experiment from both containers and also try logging the wine.csv file as an artifact using mlflow.log_artifact(<file_path>). This is probably a stupid question - but could it be because your artifact location is a hidden folder? I concur that its not reading the artifact location
